Key Laboratory of Advanced Textile Composites Ministry of Education of China Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 China Graphical abstract The review provides an overview of the research progresses of Al-based materials in various important components of solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs), with a large number of studies focusing on Al-doped materials for SSLMBs as well as Al-containing compounds materials. As the world transitions to green energy, there is a growing focus among many researchers on the requirement for high-efficient and safe batteries. Solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs) have emerged as a promising alternative to traditional liquid lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), offering higher energy density, enhanced safety, and longer lifespan. The rise of SSLMBs has brought about a transformation in energy storage, with aluminum (Al)-based material dopants playing a crucial role in advancing the next generation of batteries. The review highlights the significance of Al-based material dopants in SSLMBs applications, particularly its contributions to solid-state electrolytes (SSEs), cathodes, anodes, and other components of SSLMBs. Some studies have also shown that Al-based material dopants effectively enhance SSE ion conductivity, stabilize electrode and SSE interfaces, and suppress lithium dendrite growth, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance of SSLMBs. Despite the above mentioned progresses, there are still problems and challenges need to be addressed. The review offers a comprehensive insight into the important role of Al in SSLMBs and addresses some of the issues related to its applications, endowing valuable support for the practical implementation of SSLMBs. Keywords Al-based material dopants Solid state lithium metal batteries Solid-state electrolytes Action mechanisms and structure designs Optimization strategies 1 Introduction Currently, most of the global energy mainly comes from fossil fuels such as oil, natural gas, and coal, which dominate energy consumption for people [1–3]. However, with the continuous growth of the population, urbanization and rapid development of emerging economies, the environmental issues caused by the consumption of non-renewable energy sources are becoming increasingly prominent. Therefore, promoting the transition of society towards renewable energy is evident in the trends of developing and utilizing green and highly secure renewable energy sources [4,5]. In this process, for fully utilizing renewable energy, there is an urgent need to develop energy storage system technologies and their significant roles in the integration of new energy sources such as solar and wind power [6–8]. Among various energy storage systems, rechargeable batteries are considered one of the most promising next-generation electrochemical energy storage technologies due to their environmentally friendly nature, high energy density and power density, recharge-ability, and wide range of applications [9–12]. However, the liquid electrolyte in traditional LIBs is prone to leakage, lacks environmental friendliness, and can lead to safety issues such as thermal runaway, combustion, or explosion under extreme conditions like high temperatures or overcharging. Additionally, some liquid electrolytes often can react violently with lithium metal, forming an unstable interface, which can effectively promote lithium dendrite growth and cause battery short circuits [13–15]. Namely, the problems of safety and energy density of traditional liquid lithium batteries have not yet been fully resolved. Therefore, it is necessary to apply non-flammable solid-state electrolytes (SSE) as an alternative to liquid electrolytes [16–20]. Solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs) composed of SSEs usually exhibit excellent new battery chemical characteristics in the new energy field of high safety and excellent energy density. Unlike traditional graphite anode, metal lithium can offer a higher theoretical capacity, which can translate to longer battery life with higher energy density. The high conductivity of SSEs also can ensure that it can efficiently facilitate the movement of Li+, which is responsible for storing and providing discharge capacity in high-performance SSLMBs. Consequently, the assembled SSLMBs hold great development prospects in high-security new energy field and can provide an ideal choice for the next generation of high-performance energy storage devices [21–25]. Al-based material dopants (such as aluminium metal ion, Al2O3, AlF3/AlCl3, Li3AlH6, etc.) usually demonstrate significant potential in the battery fields. Al-based material dopants can be prepared and applied to various parts of batteries, including cathode electrode materials (such as Al-doped LiCoO2, LiMn2O4, etc.) [26–30], anode electrode materials (Al-based graphite, Al-based silicon materials, etc.) [31–34], various SSE materials (Al-doped oxide SSEs, such as Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO), Li1+ x Al x Ge2− x (PO4)3 (LAGP), Li1+ x Al x Ti2− x (PO4)3 (LATP), etc.) [35–39], and even applied in some pouch cell shell packaging [40], current collectors and so on [41,42] (Fig. 1 ). In various key components of SSLMBs, Al-based material dopants usually play a crucial role for enhancing their various performances [43–45]. Aluminum is one of the most abundant metal resources on earth, known for its lightweight, good mechanical properties, outstanding corrosion resistance, and relatively low cost. Its excellent thermal stability makes Al-based material dopants highly thermally safe in SSLMBs, significantly reducing safety risks caused by thermal runaway [46–48]. Furthermore, the most significant advantages of Al-based materials in SSLMBs are good compatibility with lithium metal anodes, greatly preventing the growth of lithium dendrites and so on. It has been shown that doping Al-based materials can form LiAl alloy possessing a low diffusion potential, thus accelerating lithium ion diffusion and preventing lithium dendrite formation. The LiAl/Li interface is also thermodynamically stable and possesses strong interfacial strength and interfacial interactions [49]. Besides, some Al-based material dopants also can effectively enhance the ion conductivity of SSEs, stabilize electrode and SSE interfaces, thus enhancing the electrochemical performance of high-performance SSLMBs. The above mentioned advantages endow these Al-based compounds with widespread applications as advanced material dopants in high-performance SSLMBs. As a large number of researches on SSLMBs make progresses, the design and optimization of Al-based material dopants are essential for enhancing the electrochemical performance and safety of SSLMBs. Researchers regulate and optimize the crystal structure, microstructure, and physicochemical properties of Al-based material dopants to achieve improved electrical conductivity, structural stability, mechanical properties and interface compatibility. For instance, reasonably controlling the doping concentration and distribution of Al elements also can optimize the material's electrical conductivity and ion migration rate. Simultaneously, employing suitable preparation methods and process parameters also can make Al-based material dopants present excellent performance [50]. In the rapid development and in-depth researches of SSLMBs, Al-based material dopants, as an important component in batteries, are expected to unleash greater application potential. The review summarizes the recent applications and researches of Al-based material dopants in SSLMBs and analyzes their mechanisms, optimization strategies, challenges, and prospects, aiming to provide scientific references for promoting their industrial applications in high-performance SSLMBs. 2 Al-based material dopants applied in SSEs SSEs are the important core of high-peroformance SSLMBs, providing not only the necessary ion transport channels, but also maintaining high electrochemical stability and safety. Thus, these researches in this area hold significant value for the fast development of high-performance SSLMBs and their practical applications. The study of Al-based materials also plays a crucial role in SSEs. Therefore, this section mainly summarized previous researches on Al-based materials in SSEs, such as LLZO-Al, Al2O3, AlF3/AlCl3, and Al-MOFs, all of which play vital roles in making it great significance to summarize and analyze them for SSEs of high-performance SSLMBs. 2.1 Al-doped materials for SSEs The metal ions (such as Al, Nb, Ta, Zr, Co, Ni, Fe, etc.) doped in SSEs play a crucial role in improving and enhancing the electrochemical performance and safety of SSEs [51–53]. Among these dopant elements, Al can offer some significant economic advantages. Introducing Al into SSEs can effectively enhance the ion conductivity of batteries and improve the ion transport performance based on the additional introduction of lithium ions through doping occupies high-energy gap sites, thereby activating the synergistic migration mechanism and opening up new migration channels, yielding positive effects for SSEs [54]. For instance, Garnet LLZO is an SSE material with high ion conductivity and good chemical stability. The cubic structure of LLZO is typically stabilized by doping with equivalent cations to maintain the critical concentration of Li+ vacancies [55]. The related experimental results showed that Al-doped LLZO SSEs exhibited excellent ion conductivity, wide electrochemical window and high thermal and excellent electrochemical stability [56]. By substituting some Zr atoms in the LLZO lattice with Al, additional vacancies can be introduced, making it more likely to replace Li sites and generate more Li vacancies. These additional vacancies also can provide more ion transport channels, greatly reducing the hindrance of lithium ions in LLZO, thereby enhancing ion transport rate and ion conductivity [57].Thus Al-doped LLZO demonstrates improved ion transport performance in SSLMBs, thereby increasing the power density and cycling performance of the assembled batteries. For instance, Jin et al. [58] applied Al-doped LLZO SSEs for high-performance SSLMBs. And as the operating temperature rose to 50 °C, both energy density and battery cycle life both significantly improve due to the notable reductions in cathode and anode interface resistance, leading to enhanced battery performance. In addition, Sun et al. [59] utilized Bragg Coherent Diffractive Imaging to investigate atomic displacements within individual grains of LLZO at different Al doping concentrations (Fig. 2 a). Simultaneously, X-ray data indicate that with increasing Al doping, a full-phase transition is activated with large strain-free crystal domains in the form of stable c-LLZO. The crystal defects induced by aluminum doping highlight the critical role of aluminum doping in changing the microstructure of individual LLZO grains, affecting the mechanical and electrical properties of LLZO. For further enhancing the ionic conductivity of SSEs, Ma et al. [60] also optimized the preparation process of Al-doped LLZO using a simple post-doping method (LLZO-Al). The resulting LLZO-Al materials exhibited a high Li+ conductivity of 5.331 × 104 S cm−1 and activation energy of 0.25 eV at room temperature. The synthesized ceramic microspheres demonstrated a compact microstructure, uniform particle size and arrangement, leading to increased relative density which can significantly improve Li+ conductivity, facilitating the ion transport during charge-discharge processes. Consequently, the prepared LLZO-Al demonstrated outstanding stability against Li in the assembled Li||LLZO-Al||Li symmetric cell using the electrolyte, and the LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811) ||LLZO-Al||Li SSLMB achieved a stable cycle of 120 cycles at 0.1 C. This research presents a cost-effective method for preparing LLZO-based SSEs with high ionic conductivities for high-energy SSLMBs (Fig. 2b). Additionally, Al co-doping system with other metal elements such as Ti, Ta, Nb, Ga, and Mg are also achieved good effect in promoting the electrochemical properties and safety of SSEs [61–67]. In terms of metal Al modifying the interfacial of SSEs and electrodes, some researchers also used Al as a buffer layer to greatly enhance the interface stability between the electrolyte and the cathode or anode electrodes. The preparation cost of Al deposition is relatively low and can reduce the contact resistance between the electrolyte and cell electrode, enhancing their compatibilities. Thereby the battery's cycle life and power output performance can be realized. For instance, depositing a metal Al buffer layer on LLZO SSE also can significantly improve the contact between the SSE and lithium anode, significantly reducing the interface resistance and preventing the obvious formation of lithium dendrites. In addition, Zhai et al. [68] constructed an ultra-thin Al-Si interface buffer layer (10 nm) on Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO), owing to the alloying reaction between the Al-Si buffer layer and Li metal, molten Li metal can wet the surface of ASL (Li/Al-Si coated LLZTO) resulting in the tight interface contact with many advantages. Additionally, the impact of different Al layer thicknesses on the interface between the SSE and lithium anode in SSLMBs varies to a certain extent. In the work of Il'ina et al. [69], they applied the vacuum deposition to cover ceramic samples with Al layers of 10, 50, and 150 nm thickness for SSLMBs (Fig. 2c). Finally, the obtained results indicate that depositing 150 nm Al can effectively improve the contact with the lithium anode and reducing the interface resistance between the SSE and Li, thus rapidly forming a stable interface at room temperature even high temperatures. However, more functions and applications of Al-based material dopants have yet to be proposed, providing direction for future researches for SSLMBs. 2.2 A2O3 compound for SSEs Al2O3, as a common low-cost Al based oxide ceramic material, possesses good thermal stability, good electrical insulation and excellent chemical stability. It is widely used in LIBs and also has a positive impact on high-performance SSLMBs [70–72]. In the field of SSLMBs, Al2O3 is not only utilized to enhance the ion conductivity and mechanical strength of the electrolyte, but also for protecting lithium anode [73]. Nanoscale inert Al2O3, compared to micrometer-sized LAGP and LLZO, can form a continuous phase when doped in preparing polymer composite solid electrolytes, thereby enhancing ion conductivity of SSE, improving interface stability between cell electrodes and SSE and increasing thermal stability of SSE. The addition of an appropriate amount of Al2O3 also can significantly enhance the performance and reliability of SSLMBs. For instance, Lee et al. [74] proposed a low sintering temperature (520 °C) to prepare the Li2O-B2O3-Al2O3 oxide glass electrolyte which can be co-sintered with the electrodes. The prepared Al2O3 was applied as an intermediary material, greatly increasing the mechanical strength and chemical stability of the obtained electrolyte due to high vacancy concentration of Al3+. For instance, He et al. [75] combined nano Al2O3 particles with poly (vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene)-grafted polyrotaxane to design and develop a hybrid polymer electrolyte for high-performance SSLMBs. The obtained lewis acid-type Al2O3 and abundant fluorine can accelerate the dissociation of lithium salts (Fig. 3 a), significantly improving Li+ conductivity and transfer number. While the rich hydroxyl functional groups on the surface of Al2O3 with fluorinated hydrogen branches also can enhance mechanical strength of the prepared SSE. For enhancing the Li+ transfer number, Yu et al. [76] incorporated the Al2O3 into Li1.3Al0.3Ge1.7P3O12 (LAGP) based mixed SSEs, aiming to increase the Li+ migration number of the obtained SSE due to the anion scavenging effect of Al2O3 (Fig. 3b). Furthermore, the excellent thermal stability and durability of the mixed composite electrolyte can be attributed to the excellent heat resistance of Al2O3 [77]. For example, Liu et al. [78] designed and prepared an asymmetric bi-functional composite solid-state electrolyte achieving compatibility with Li anode and high-voltage anode to extend the cycle life of batteries. The result showed that the addition of asymmetric nanofibrous membrane (AHPAA) not only can provide a substrate with sufficient mechanical properties and the channels through which Li+ can be continuously transported for the polyethylene oxide (PEO)-based solid-state electrolytes, but also makes it compatible with the high-voltage cathode through taking advantage of the synergistic effects of the asymmetric properties (Fig. 3c). In addition, Al2O3 fibers especially nanofibers have a high specific surface area and aspect ratio, greatly enabling the formation of long and continuous contact interfaces with the polymer matrix. The prepared electrolyte can provide more facilitated Li+ transport channels, and exhibits good interface compatibility with lithium anodes due to long-range ordered structure of electrolyte, thereby playing a more active role in SSLMBs. Recently, Yu et al. [79] innovatively and efficiently prepared Al2O3 nanofibers and deposited an aqueous dispersion of Al2O3 into a membrane, via vacuum filtration to construct a nanofiber membrane with a three-dimensional network structure as the backbone of a PEO-based solid-state electrolyte (Fig. 3d). The supporting effect of the nanofiber network structure improved the mechanical properties of the reinforced composite solid-state electrolyte and its ability to inhibit the growth of Li dendrites. Furthermore, Li et al. [80] also prepared a flexible-rigid composite solid electrolyte film by incorporating different weight ratios (5–20 wt%) of γ-Al2O3 fibers into the flexible polypropylene oxide (PPO) polymer electrolytes for high-performance SSLMBs. The addition of γ-Al2O3 fibers also can shorten the ion migration pathways, effectively improving the ion migration rate. Moreover, the strong Lewis acid groups of γ-Al2O3 fibers can effectively react with TFSI− to release more Li+, thus enhancing Li+ migration. With 15 wt% of γ-Al2O3 fibers, the room-temperature ionic conductivity can reach as high as 3.38 × 10−4 S cm−1 with high ion migration number of 0.70 and the wide electrochemical window of 5.6 V. Additionally, the prepared lithiophilic γ-Al2O3 also can react with metal Li form a Li-Al-O transition layer, facilitating Li+ interfacial transport and uniform Li deposition and also inhibiting Li dendrite growth. The prepared Al2O3 fiber-reinforced composite solid electrolyte (CSE) showed promising practical applications in high-performance SSLMBs (Fig. 3e). Especially due to the intimate connection between Al2O3 and metallic lithium, the rapid formation of a Li+ layer can effectively promote the uniform lithium deposition, significantly prevent lithium dendrite growth during long-term cycling, and enhance the ionic conductivity of SSE for high-performance SSLMBs, thus improving the cycling stability with high charge-discharge efficiency [81,82]. Surface modification of garnet-type SSEs by Deng et al. resulted in a thin γ-Al2O3 surface coating layer on the garnet matrix [83]. The obtained γ-Al2O3 coating layer can facilitate the phase transition from tetragonal to cubic phases, thereby greatly stabilizing the cubic garnet phase. Additionally, incorporating Al2O3 as part of the electrolyte can form a dense interfacial layer which effectively hinders direct contact between the electrolyte and cell electrode, enhancing interface stability between the cathode and electrolyte, lowering electrolyte loss and reducing electrode side reactions [84]. For instance, Zhang et al. [85] constructed a non-conductive Al2O3 layer at the lithium metal and LLZO interface through magnetron sputtering and annealing pathways. The assembled battery exhibited good structural stability, enabling 1000 cycles, with the design of the Al2O3 intermediate layer promoting uniform lithium deposition reactions and inhibiting the serious lithium dendrite growth. Furthermore, Sudo et al. [86] doped Al2O3 into the garnet-type SSE through solid state reaction of high temperature of 1180 °C. The influences of different Al2O3 contents on the behavior at the lithium metal interface were investigated. The study revealed that the interface resistance of Al2O3-doped LLZO was tightly correlated with various Al2O3 contents, with the lowest interface resistance and the highest relative density observed for 0.5 wt% Al2O3-doped LLZO. In addition, Pei et al. [87] introduced nano Al2O3 fillers into a polycaprolactone (PCL) matrix using a solution casting method, forming an closely in-situ Li-Al-O interface layer between CPEs and Li metal anodes. The obtained stable Li-Al-O interface layers effectively suppressed lithium dendrite growth, thereby stabilizing the electrode/SSE interface. 2.3 AlF3/AlCl3 compounds AlF3 is a strong Lewis acid which can effectively adsorb anions and has low electronic conductivity. It is widely used in SSEs to promote the dissociation of lithium salts, reduce the nucleation overpotential during lithium cycling, suppress lithium dendrite growth, and enhance battery performance and stability for high-performance SSLMBs. Recent studies have introduced AlF3 for the preparation of solid polymer electrolytes [88]. AlF3 can be acted as a Lewis acid catalyst and well build a fluoride cathode-electrolyte interface layer for protecting the electrolyte and Al current collector from degradation reactions. Meanwhile, adding AlF3 to the electrolyte also can improve the stability of the anode, thus greatly extending the battery's cycle life. The applied approach can also be extended to other electrolyte systems to further enhance stability and compatibility with high-voltage cathodes [89]. The development of SSLMBs through in-situ polymerization is considered a promising option for commercial applications due to excellent flexibility, high energy density and well safety. However, some issues such as undesirable side reactions and lithium dendrite growth are common due to unstable electrode/electrolyte interfaces and slow ion diffusion kinetics, leading to low efficiency and short lifespan of SSLMBs. For instance, Zhang et al. [90] introduced AlF3 as a Lewis acid additive in a three-dimensional (3D) crosslinked in-situ semi-solid-state polymer electrolyte through in-situ polymerization method. The obtained results showed that the applied AlF3 can greatly immobilize anions and form a robust solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer with fast Li+ diffusion kinetics to effectively protect the Li metal anode and significantly improve electrochemical properties. The result mainly was due to the presence of LiF, lithiophilic Li-Al alloy, and AlF3 species during the charge-discharge processes (Fig. 4 a). The stabilized SEI layer can enhance the electrochemical performance of the cell and avoid rapid fade of capacity and Coulombic efficiency [91]. The preparation approach also can offer valuable insights for enhancing the commercial application of SSLMBs with in-situ polymerized SSEs. For further overcoming the traditional interface charge transfer issues, Wang et al. [92] introduced AlF3 into PEO, successfully developing a high-performance solid polymer electrolyte. The prepared AlF3 increased the concentration of free Li+, enhancing the ion transfer number of the composite electrolyte and the interface stability of lithium metal/electrolyte. Additionally, it also further promoted the in-situ formation of a fluorine-rich lithium interface layer, facilitating uniform Li+ deposition. For instance, Hu et al. [88] also incorporated mesoporous α-AlF3 nanoparticles with high specific surface area into a PEO matrix to prepare a highly fluorinated polymer electrolyte. The corresponding result demonstrated that the polymer electrolyte containing AlF3 particles could achieve a Li+ transfer number of 0.67 at 60 °C, which was rather beneficial for the formation of the ionically conductive component in the SSE interface, while inhibiting the serious dendritic growth. To further improve the lithium-ion transport capability of the composite electrolyte, Liu et al. [93] innovatively proposed the spiny inorganic nanofibers (SINF) heterostructure with mullite whiskers grown on the surface of AlF3 nanofibers into the PEO-LiTFSI electrolytes. The 3D structure further increases the effective contact interface with the PEO polymer enabled Li+ to transport not only along the large aspect ratio of AlF3 nanofibers but also rapidly across the membrane direction of mica phase (Fig. 4b), further enhancing the Li+ transport pathway, and the composite solid-state electrolyte exhibits high ionic conductivity to 1.58 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 30 °C and lithium-ion transfer number to 0.53. Furthermore, AlF3 can also be served as a surface coating material with good interface stability, effectively preventing side reactions between the SSE and electrode materials. For instance, Lu et al. [94] constructed an ultra-thin superhydrophilic but hydrophobic AlF3 layer on the surface of LLZTO particles through in-situ conversion reaction, achieving a super-lithiophilic, moisture-resistant, and robust interface for high-performance SSLMBs. The low conductivity lithium fluoride layer can be acted as an electronic insulating layer, significantly preventing electrons from entering LLZTO, thereby suppressing lithium dendrite growth at grain boundaries and LLZTO interfaces. In addition, Gu et al. [95] proposed a porous layer method using high-surface AlF3 (HS-AlF3) as a LATP electrolyte. The formed AlF3 interlayer can effectively prevent physical contact between the lithium anode and LATP electrolyte, greatly improving the battery system's volume change pressure and facilitating lithium salt dissociation and rapid Li+ migration. Moreover, the hybrid solid-liquid electrolyte study is an effective approach to address interface issues between SSEs and Li anodes/cathodes. However, the formation of a solid-liquid electrolyte layer at the interfaces also can lead to the decreased battery capacity and power over extended cycles due to reactive chemical and electrochemical reactions. For tackling this challenge, Sarkar et al. [96] demonstrated a synthetic method by incorporating AlCl3 Lewis acid and fluoroethylene carbonate additives in a conventional LiPF6-containing carbonate-based electrolyte (Fig. 4c). The novel electrolyte design can effectively initiate the fluoroethylene carbonate polymerization through AlCl3, resulting in the formation of a mechanically robust and ionically conductive Al-rich interphase on the surface of Li7La2.75Ba0.25Zr1.75Ta0.25O12 garnet-type structured SSEs, Li anodes and LiNi0.6Mn0.2Co0.2O2 (NCM622) cathodes. The obtained innovative approach can enable the Li symmetric cell to achieve a high critical current density of 4.2 mA cm−2 and stable cycling for over 3000 h at 0.5 mA cm−2 at 25 °C. The full cell also exhibited impressive specific capacity retention of 92.2% after 200 cycles even at 1 C. The research way aimed to mitigate side reactions between conventional organic electrolytes and garnet-type SSE interfaces while enhancing the stability of anode and cathode interphases, resulting in significant battery performance enhancements for the final battery. 2.4 Al-MOF structure Al-MOF plays a positive role in improving the performance of SSEs as their fillers. The result is due to the unique porous structure framework of MOFs and abundant reserves of Al elements [97]. The prepared electrolyte can replace separators and liquid electrolytes in traditional batteries, directly used for rapid charging and discharging in SSLMBs. For instance, Zhu et al. [98] prepared and utilized Al-MOF, 1, 4-benzenedicarboxylate (MIL-53(Al)) as a filler for PEO-based thin film electrolytes to obtain the PEO-MIL-53(Al)-lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) electrolytes. The MIL-53(Al) nanoparticles with Lewis acidic surfaces can effectively promote the dissolution of LiTFSI, thereby enhancing Li+ conductivity, increasing thermal stability, and improving mechanical strength of the prepared electrolyte. Furthermore, Gerbaldi et al. [99] demonstrated long-term stable interface properties and enhanced ionic conductivity at ambient temperatures by incorporating Al-MOF successfully dispersed in a PEO-based polymer matrix. In utilizing space structure to dope aluminum, other material dopants like clay are also used in solid-state electrolytes. When applied in SSLMBs, these can effectively suppress serious lithium dendrite growth, showing good cycling performance and cathode compatibility. For instance, Mao et al. [100] proposed a method to prepare a new solid electrolyte (Li-IL@Al-PILC) using nano 2D interlayer structures of Al pillared clay (Al-PILC). The prepared Li-IL@Al-PILC obtained through impregnation exhibited high ionic conductivity (2.13 × 10−3 S cm−1), good thermal stability (up to 450 °C), an extremely wide electrochemical window (up to 5.5 V), low interfacial resistance, and high mechanical strength. Finally, Al-based material dopants are widely used in SSEs, with diverse types and significant enhancement effects. And Table 1 shows the performance indicators of Al-based materials in solid-state electrolytes, paving the way for more practically applicable SSEs through structural design and optimization, thereby promoting the industrialization and widespread adoption of SSLMBs. 3 Al-based material dopants applied in cathode Besides SSEs, cathode electrode materials also play a critical role in SSLMBs, determining the battery's energy density and cycling stability. Al-based materials, known for their merits such as lightweight and structural stability, can greatly enhance Li+ participation in the charging and discharging processes through compounds such as Al-doped materials or Al2O3. Additionally, the excellent stability is also crucial for greatly improving the interface performance by embedding some Al-based materials in high-performance SSLMBs, thereby increasing the battery's storage performance. 3.1 Al-doped materials for cathode The designing of cell cathodes is essential regardless of whether utilizing SSEs or liquid electrolytes for batteries due to their key components of any batteries, which play a vital role [101,102]. Meanwhile, the application of Al-based material dopants in the cathode of SSLMBs is also gaining large traction due to its potential role to improve battery efficiency, safety, and longevity. The role of Al-based material dopants in SSLMB cathodes is primarily focused on their strong ability to stabilize the cathode structure and facilitate the fast conduction of Li+. For instance, in the preparation of NCM cathode materials, Al not only stabilizes the structure of the NCM, but also Al-doping expands the interlayer spacing of NCM, thereby improving the ion diffusion migration rate and suppressing lithium dendrite growth [103–107]. But up to now, designing fast-charging, long-cycle and high-voltage cathode materials has remained a challenge. Avoiding the adverse phase transition of SSLMBs caused by high voltage, optimizing the Li+ diffusion kinetics, and improving the process to ensure cycle safety are the issues that need to be focused on and solved in the design the cathode by using Al-doped materials. To address these problems, Sun et al. [108] addressed high-performance cathodes by incorporating Al and Nb/W into LiCoO2 at the Co- and Li-sites (Fig. 5 a). Their findings presented that Al-doping at the Co-site can effectively prevent undesirable phase changes even under high voltage. And the obtained Nb/W dopants within the Li can be acted as pillars, which can significantly enhance interlayer spacing, reduce electronic coupling around Li+, promote active Li+ presence, and facilitate rapid Li+ diffusion kinetics. Meanwhile, Thirunakaran et al. [109] designed and synthesized LiMn2O4 and LiNi x Al y Mn2− x − y O4 (x = 0.50; y = 0.05–0.50) using the sol-gel method as cell cathode. The doping of Al in the preparation process can ensure the uniform mixing of the mixture due to structural rearrangement. For example, Xia et al. [110] used Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O, and Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O as raw materials, with organic acids as chelating agents, to controllably prepare LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathode materials through the corresponding drying and high-temperature sintering processes (Fig. 5b). The various choices of different chelating agents during preparation also have a certain impact on the final product's performance. The coating method for cell cathode also plays a rather important role in delaying the degradation of electrochemical performance and safety in batteries. However, developing cathode coatings with high ionic conductivity and good interfacial stability with cathode materials still has been challenging up to today. For another instance, Liu et al. [111] conducted the detailed computational studies on the phase stability, thermodynamic stability, and ionic transport properties of LiMXO4F (M-X = Al–P and Mg–S) used as cathode coatings for SSLMBs (Fig. 5c). These coatings exhibited high oxidative stability and good electrochemical stability even under high-voltage cathodes. Additionally, they also demonstrated high chemical stability can be realized when in contact with some oxide cathodes. The Li+ transport pathways and migration barriers of LiMXO4F were deeply studied with low migration barriers of 0.19 and 0.09 eV, which were considered promising cathode coating layer, with LiAlPO4F based on Al being experimentally validated. The computational methods for theoretical cathode coatings presented in this study can be applied to high-performance SSLMBs. 3.2 Al2O3 compound for cathode For enhancing the structural stability of cathode and electrochemical performance of SSLMB using cathode materials, some researchers have employed various modification methods for Al-based material dopants. Among them, Al2O3 as a surface coating layer significantly improves the structural stability and also creates a composite material that allows for faster Li+ diffusion, thus significantly promoting the electrochemical performance and safety of the cathode material, becoming one of the most studied oxide materials [112–114]. For instance, Woo et al. [115] introduced Al2O3 layer through atomic layer deposition (ALD) in LiCoO2 cathode. The insulating properties of the Al2O3 layer led to a decrease in the initial discharge capacity of the assembled battery with increasing layers of Al2O3 (Fig. 6 a). The Al2O3 layer on the active material effectively modifies the cathode and SSE interface, greatly reducing the interface resistance between LiCoO2 and the SSE, significantly suppressing capacity decay during cell cycle and greatly enhancing the cyclic performance of the SSLMB. To effectively achieve stable electrode/electrolyte interface contact, Chen et al. [116] designed and prepared the Al2O3@LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 composite material, effectively increasing the cathode Li+ transfer pathway and significantly improving the stability of the cathode/electrolyte interfaces. Successfully assembled into a SSLMB, it exhibited excellent electrochemical performance at 55 °C (Fig. 6b). Meanwhile, employing an in-situ polymerization method can significantly reduce interface impedance and suppress lithium dendrite formation, thus resulting in SSLMBs with good cyclic and rate performance [117]. The main factors affecting the electrochemical performance of Ni-rich oxide cathodes for sulfide-based SSLMBs also include interface side reactions and mechanical failures. It is believed that the interface side reaction is mainly due to high nickel content and residual lithium compounds on the surface. While mechanical failure is mainly caused by the significant volume changes during cycling, Li et al. [118] developed the core-shelled Ni-rich Li(Ni0.9Mn0.05Co0.05)0.8Co0.2O2, further modified with Al. The applied approach involves designing a core-shell structure for the Ni-rich oxide material to greatly reduce surface nickel content and minimize volume changes (Fig. 6c). By modifying the surface of the core-shelled Ni-rich oxide material with Al isopropoxide, an Al-modifying layer (Al2O3 and LiAlO2 layer) can be formed, removing lithium compounds, and forming a coating layer. Even with a high mass loading of 36.94 mg cm−2, the Al-modified Li(Ni0.9Mn0.05Co0.05)0.8Co0.2O2 (CS-NCM@Al) cathode exhibits a significant capacity retention of 96.3% after 500 cycles at 1 C (7.39 mA cm−2). Other Al-based coating materials, such as AlF3 and AlPO4, with low cost, high structural stability, and high performance, are also desirable in the cathode of SSLMBs [119]. Until now, significant researches have been conducted on this advancement in LIBs, and the performance parameters of SSLMB cathode aluminum-based materials are shown in Table 2 . However, further studies about the working mechanism in high-performance SSLMBs are still required [120,121]. 4 Al-based material dopants applied in anode The anode electrode material in SSLMBs is equally crucial, directly influencing the battery's capacity and cycle life. The ideal anode electrode materials should possess high Li+ diffusion rates and good electrochemical stability. The development of novel anode electrode materials also plays a significant role in enhancing the performance of high-performance SSLMBs. And Al-based materials also exhibit several excellent characteristics in electrochemical performance, such as LiAl alloy, Al-MOFs, and Li3AlH6 performing well as anode electrodes. They also play a key role in addressing interface issues, ion transport problems, lithium dendrite issues, and are important directions for future researches. 4.1 LiAl alloy materials for anode Aluminum anodes can provide multiple electron transfers in a single redox reaction, so their volumetric capacity is about four times that of lithium anodes to a certain extent. Even though the ionic radius of Al3+ is smaller than that of Li+, their strong binding to the host structure limits their mobility [122]. Up to now, besides Sn, Li, and Si being used for alloy-type anode electrode materials, Al has also been proven to be a promising alloy-type anode electrode material [123]. Al is a metal with a face-centered cubic structure, with tetrahedral void sizes close to that of Li+, making it highly prone to forming intermetallic compounds with Li+, such as LiAl alloy or Li3Al2 and Li4Al3 for cell anode of SSLMBs [124,125]. LiAl alloy has been shown to be a stable and reversible anode electrode with a high theoretical specific capacity of 993 mA h g−1, which is 2.67 times that of graphite (372 mA h g−1) [126]. Al with inherently and highly safe reactivity can effectively suppress lithium dendrite growth when paired with SSEs, thereby enhancing the overall safety of the battery. The related research by Huang et al. [127] aimed to evaluate the lithium dendrite suppression capability of various common Li alloys, including Li-Zn, Li-Si, Li-Sn, and Li-Al. It was observed that despite medium lithium content and a 3D alloy/solid electrolyte composite structure, some alloys still experienced soft shorting of SSLMBs (Fig. 7 a). Among all the studied alloy anodes, the obtained Li-Al demonstrated the highest dendrite formation suppression capability, which mainly was ascribed to the LiAl alloy possessing a low diffusion potential, accelerating lithium atom diffusion, preventing lithium dendrite formation. It was also found that LiAl alloy can be served as a protective layer or as a framework for guiding the uniform lithium deposition, making it a widely used material in high performance SSLMBs. In high current density conditions, the even distribution of Li+ flux and uniform mass transfer are crucial for LiAl alloy, which also plays a significant role in inhibiting side reactions and significantly reducing interfacial resistance. The 3D structure of LiAl alloy as the anode electrode can further enhance the lithium transport dynamics [124]. Creating a 3D lithium metal anode has been proven as the most effective solution for tackling lithium dendrite formation in liquid batteries. However, implementing this approach in SSLMBs has been still challenging due to the inflexibility of inorganic SSEs, which significantly limits solid-solid ionic contact at the interface. In this study, a 3D Li anode is spontaneously formed for SSLMBs through chemical reactions between halide SSEs and Li metal. The resulting Li-Al alloys and well-preserved sulfide SSEs within the 3D framework can be acted as continuous pathways for electron and Li+ transport, and effectively promote even distribution of charge carriers. The lithiophilic Li alloy also helps regulate Li deposition, thus ensuring uniform nucleation and deposition of Li. Both the Li||Li symmetric cells and full batteries demonstrated excellent electrochemical performances even under high current densities. The corresponding research introduces a universal approach and fresh perspective for constructing 3D Li structures in high-performance SSLMBs. In addition, LiAl alloys outperform other alloy-type anodes, such as tin-based and silicon-based alloys. LiAl alloys exhibit consistent lithium insertion/extraction potentials and a faster Li+ diffusion coefficient when applied in anode of SSLMBs. For instance, Zheng et al. [128] have proposed a successful method to achieve long-term cycling of plain Al foil anodes, and the obtained β-LiAl phase grown from Al foil (α-Al) demonstrated a good cycling life of 500 cycles with around 96% capacity retention when coupled with a commercial cathode (Fig. 7b). The obtained superior performance mainly is attributed to the strategic utilization of the Li solubility range of β-LiAl, allowing for lithiation and delithiation without altering its corresponding crystal structure. The solubility range at room temperature is approximately at 6%. The design can effectively address critical issues related to phase transformations (α/β/α), such as volume variations, mechanical stress, and nanopore formation. In terms of application, the advanced state of the Al industry, along with promising sustainability prospects, positions this anode as a significant choice based on Al-based material dopants for future devices. The practical use of a lithium anode in SSLMB can be hindered by uncontrolled lithium dendrite growth and poor interfacial contact with solid electrolyte and electrodes. For instance, Zhang et al. [129] induced a uniform distribution of interface electric field by forming a LiAl buffer layer through in-situ alloying reaction for high-performance SSLMB, which greatly suppressed side reactions between SSE and lithium metal and reduced lithium dendrite formation, thus enhancing the cycling performance of SSLMBs. For well optimizing the lithium metal anode, Zhu et al. [130] designed and developed a 40 µm thin lithium composite anode using the AlN-embedded reduced graphene oxide (rGO) scaffold through one-step molten lithium infusion (Fig. 7c). The resulting lithiophilic Li-Al alloy with highly ion-conductive Li3N can create Li+ diffusion pathways within the cell electrode, facilitating well-oriented lithium deposition and effectively inhibiting lithium dendrite growth. By combining in-situ polymerization and Li3N-modified SEI, the composite anodes extended the symmetric cell lifespan to 2100 h at 0.2 mA cm−2/0.2 mA h cm−2 in carbonate-based solid polymer electrolytes. The modified electrode presented a promising approach to design and assemble high-performance SSLMBs. Furthermore, in the work of Fan et al. [131], a mechanically prelithiated Al foil (MP-Al-H) was utilized as an anode to fabricate high-performance SSLMBs with sulfide electrolyte. The formed dense Li-Al layer of the MP-Al-H foil can be served as a prelithiated anode, forming a 2D interface with the sulfide electrolyte. While the un-lithiated Al layer also can be acted as a tightly bound current collector, ensuring the structural integrity of the electrode. The study can provide a pathway to well address interfacial and performance challenges in the application of high-performance SSLMBs. 4.2 Al-MOFs for anode Al-based MOFs with excellent cycling stability, high specific surface area and wide pore distribution can significantly mitigate the volume changes of Li and enhance electron transfer. For instance, Zhang et al. [132] designed and fabricated the Al2O3@MOF-loaded mesoporous carbon (Al2O3@MOF-C) as a stable host matrix for lithium metal. In the composite, the applied Al2O3 can be served as nanoscale seeds for lithium deposition, reducing lithium nucleation overpotential. Furthermore, Hu et al. [133] developed accordion-like nanostructured carbon materials (ALNCs) based on Al-MOF with micropores and mesopores. When used as a kind of anode material to produce Na-ion batteries, the high invertible specific capacity of ALNCs electrode achieved 211.5 mA h g−1 based on a current density of 100 mA g−1. In addition, it also shows good cycling stability featured by a capacity retention ratio of 97% after 200 cycles (Fig. 8 a). Tong et al. [134] also designed and fabricated a novel Al-based MOF preparation technique with citric acid as the organic ligand and introduced polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) in an eco-friendly manner to adjust the stacking arrangement of MOF nanosheets, providing a flower-like hierarchical MOF structure. These methods can effectively relieve stress, increase the contact area with the electrolyte, enhance the structural stability of the electrode during cycling and improve the Li+ diffusion rate during the charge-discharge processes. 4.3 Complex aluminum hydrides and others for anode Additionally, metal hydrides exhibit the lowest polarization among all conversion-type anodes, a key advantage for practical batteries. In this case, complex aluminum hydrides such as NaAlH4, LiAlH4, and Li3AlH6 can also be used in the anode materials of SSLMBs. However, the full potentials of NaAlH4 and LiAlH4 are very difficult to reach, as poor reversibility, cycling stability, and rate capability prevent alanates from practical use. Two key disadvantages are responsible for the unsatisfactory electrochemical performances: (i) bad kinetics derived from phase segregation and particle pulverization; (ii) intensive side reactions between electrolytes and highly reductive [AlH4]− or [AlH6]3− anions [135]. For the particle pulverization, Yang et al. [136] designed and developed a high-performance Li3AlH6 anode through a solid-state ion exchange process involving a LiBH4 electrolyte and Na3AlH6. The initial discharge capacity of the Li3AlH6 anode was 1722 mA h g−1 with a minimal capacity loss of 15% in the first charge. Even after 150 cycles, the Li3AlH6 anode still maintained a capacity of 990 mA h g−1 with close to 100% Coulombic efficiency (Fig. 8b). The significant capacity enhancement during cycling was attributed to the impact of Al electrochemical milling on the active material. And Pang et al. [137] introduced an innovative solid-state prelithiation method to create a Li3AlH6-Al nanocomposite through an electrochemical reaction involving LiAlH4 and Li, which facilitated by fast electron and Li-ion conductors (C and LiBH4). The prepared composite, comprising dispersed Al nanograins and an amorphous Li3AlH6 matrix, can demonstrate the enhanced electrochemical performance in solid-state cells. The corresponding analysis also indicated that the dispersed Al nanograins and amorphous Li3AlH6 matrix can significantly improve the lithiation and delithiation kinetics without side reactions, contributing to the overall excellent performance. Therefore, Li3AlH6 composite hydride showed good application prospects as anode in high-performance solid-state lithium batteries. Moreover, other Al based materials like Al94.5In5.5 have been extensively studied in LIBs [138]. For example, Liu et al. [139] presented non-pre-lithiated Al-foil-based negative electrodes with tailored microstructures in a SSLMB configuration (Fig. 8c). Combining a 30-μm-thick Al94.5In5.5 negative electrode with a Li6PS5Cl SSE and a NCM622 cathode electrode, the laboratory-scale cells exhibited hundreds of stable cycles with practical areal capacities at high current density (6.5 mA cm−2). The corresponding result demonstrated that the multiphase Al-In microstructure significantly enhanced rate performance and reversibility by incorporating a distributed LiIn network within the Al matrix. In all, these findings highlighted the potential for enhanced SSLMBs through the metallurgical design of anode electrodes, streamlining manufacturing processes. However, further researches and explorations towards these materials are still needed in high-performance SSLMBs, and the data of anode aluminum-based materials can be used as a reference for researchers as shown in Table 3 . 5 Al-based material dopants for other contents of SSLMBs The enhancement of SSLMBs performance mainly relies on the synergy of various components. Besides playing a crucial role in cell SSEs and cathode/anode, Al-based materials are also equally significant in other components such as the current collector and aluminum-plastic film, and so on. Therefore, this section can provide a detailed analysis and summary of Al-based materials in the current collector, aluminum-plastic film, and other aspects. Growing research interest in SSLMBs within the battery community is due to their enhanced safety features. Various studies have focused on cell electrodes and electrolytes, and the current collector modification is an indispensable component in LIBs [140–143]. In general, Al foil current collectors play a crucial role in collecting and conducting electrons, typically used as carriers for collecting and distributing cathode currents, enabling electron conduction from the electrode to the external circuit. The assembled form can help to reduce the internal resistance of LIBs, greatly enhancing the battery's rate performance, coulombic efficiency, and cycling stability. Its mechanical strength also ensures that the current collector remains stable over time, greatly reducing the risk of battery degradation. The lightweight nature is another benefit for current collectors of high-performance SSLMBs. By using Al current collectors, the overall weight of the battery pack can be decreased, contributing to improved energy efficiency and electrochemical performance. The high compatibility of Al with a wide range of SSEs is also an advantage in SSLMB current collectors. Additionally, aluminum foil is relatively stable in the air. It can readily reacts with oxygen in the air to form a dense oxide film on the surface, greatly preventing further reactions and providing some protection to the applied Al [144]. However, under certain electrochemical conditions, Al current collectors are prone to corroding, leading to poor electrical and mechanical contact between the cathode electrode material and the Al foil, resulting in reduced capacity and power attenuation. Corrosion of Al foil leads to pitting on the surface, causing poor contact between the cathode material and the current collector, increasing interfacial resistance and contact impedance, thereby causing capacity decay and reducing coulombic efficiency [145–147]. All in all, it is important to improve the Al current collectors by using aluminum means, for example, the use of AlF3 as both a Lewis acid catalyst and a builder of the fluorinated cathode-electrolyte interface can protect the electrolyte and aluminum current collector from degradation reactions [89]. Some studies suggest that when compared to commercial Al foil, Al foam usually exhibits more significant advantages in SSLMBs. Due to its high porosity and 3D network structure, Al foam enhances electrode conductivity and increases the loading weight of active materials by more than 7 times that of traditional electrodes. To effectively address the low conductivity issue of high-loading electrodes based on Al foil in SSLMBs, Zhang et al. [148] proposed the application of 3D through-hole Al foam as current collectors for high-loading NCM622 electrodes in SSLMBs (Fig. 9 a). Substituting Al foam for commercial Al foil significantly boosted the areal specific capacity, increasing it from 0.4 to 1.3, 1.4, and 1.6 mA h cm−2 for varying thicknesses of Al foams. Moreover, the energy density of SSLMBs with Al foam-based electrodes was about 2.5–3 times higher than that of Al foil-based SSLMBs. Al foam shows promising potential as an electrode current collector for high-performance SSLMBs. However, the application of Al foam in SSLMBs is still in its early stages, requiring further experimentation and optimization for more functional modifications and applications. In a study by Sun Kim et al. [149], the corresponding electrochemical stabilities of Cu and Al current collectors in a PEO-based SSE containing LiTFSI salt was investigated for SSLMB (Fig. 9b). The formation of a Cu-F layer on the CuO passive layer was found to potentially delay unwanted reactions such as corrosion role. Additionally, Al metal exhibited stable passivation up to 5 V, forming outer Al-F and inner Al-O layers. These formed layers were attributed to the interaction of Al and O from the decomposed PEO, leading to the formation of Al2O3 and HF. The successful passivation observed on Cu and Al metal surfaces confirmed their suitability as current collectors for SSLMBs. Furthermore, Qi et al. [150] also successfully produced a LiMn0.5Ni0.3Co0.2O2 thin film on an Al-doped ZnO transparent current collector through a straightforward one-step synthesis. A comparison of the structure and electrochemical properties was made before and after the cycling process. The obtained Al-doped ZnO current collector demonstrated remarkable stability post-cycling (Fig. 9c). The corresponding achievement of integrating the cathode on glass substrates and utilizing optical-based failure analysis offers a valuable method for potential in operando analysis on SSLMBs. For instance, Deng et al. [151] conducted a study on the evolution of interfaces between Al foil current collectors and composite cathodes in assembled LiCoO2/Li3InCl6 (LCO/LIC) ASSLIBs at temperatures of 25 and −10 °C. The findings suggested that the primary issue affecting the interfacial stability of the current collector at 25 °C was the side reactions between Al foil and LIC. Introducing a graphene-like carbon (GLC) coating on Al effectively can effectively prevent side reactions at the interface of the current collector, leading to enhanced cycling stability and increased rate capability. Until now, research on current collectors in SSLMBs is still limited, and further exploration also is needed for more modified strategies [152]. Additionally, new forms of Al structural materials for current collectors also warrant research. Moreover, due to the advantages of mechanical properties, corrosion resistance, and thermal conductivity, Al presents a significant role in the context of SSLMBs. Such as the high resistance of Al to expansion-induced stress can be well-suited to handle the volume changes of batteries that occur during charge-discharge cycles without fracturing. The obtained durability is essential for maintaining the structural integrity of the battery and ensuring long-term performance for the cell. The chemical stability of Al also allows it to resist corrosion even in challenging environments, which is essential for maintaining the longevity of the assembled battery. Currently, Al2O3 coatings have been shown to serve as effective artificial SEIs in anode-free lithium-metal batteries, which not only improves the corrosion resistance of the anode but also prevents the excessive decomposition of the electrolyte, resulting in higher Coulombic efficiencies [153]. The obtained resistance to corrosion also helps to prevent the formation of harmful chemical reactions which could compromise the safety and performance of the SSLMB. And the SSLMBs generate also can produce much heat during operation, and effective heat dissipation is crucial for preventing overheating and maintaining performance. Thus, the high thermal conductivity of Al-based materials dopants can enable it to quickly transfer heat away from the battery's interior, reducing the risk of thermal runaway and ensuring the battery operates within safe temperature limits. 6 Summary and perspective Al-based material dopants exhibit significant potential in the application of key components such as SSEs, cathode materials, anode materials and current collectors in high-performance SSLMBs. The review provides an overview of the research progress of Al-based material dopants in various important components of SSLMBs, with a large number of studies focusing on Al-doped materials for SSLMBs as well as Al-containing compounds materials. They show promise in enhancing SSE ion conductivity, stabilizing electrode and SSE interfaces, and inhibiting serious lithium dendrite growth, thereby greatly improving the electrochemical performance and safety of high-performance SSLMBs. The summary and analysis of this research progress provides a direction for the application of Al-based material dopants in batteries, promotes the synergistic development of Al-based material dopants and SSLMBs, and further lays the foundation for the commercial development of SSLMBs. Although much progress has been made in recent years in researching Al-based material dopants to improve SSLMBs performance, many challenges remain before they can be fully utilized for electrochemical applicability (Fig. 10 ). (1) The ionic conductivity of the SSE and its interfacial compatibility with the electrodes are critical and affect the energy density and electrochemical stability of SSLMBs. Some Al-based compounds in composite SSE provide interfacial channels for Li+ transport and inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. There has been a lot of research in this regard to demonstrate the role it plays. Although there have been generalized studies on the mechanism of action of Al-based compounds in SSE, many in-depth questions remain to be explored. Therefore, it is necessary to explore the role of Al-based material dopants in high-performance SSLMBs in the future based on in-depth theoretical studies and reaction mechanisms. In addition, some inert Al-based material dopants can provide interfacial paths for Li+ conduction in composite SSE but do not possess Li+ conductivity on their own, making it difficult to meet the performance requirements of high-rate performance and long cycle life of SSLMBs. Therefore, it is necessary to develop novel composite SSE with Al-based material dopants through the collaboration of material modification and preparation processes. On the one hand, special structures can be tailored through structural optimization to achieve fast and orderly Li+ transport. On the other hand, it is possible to form vacancies through elemental doping or to make the Al-based material dopants inherently capable of Li+ transport. (2) Improvement in preparation methods and optimization of materials not only facilitate ion transport but are also the key to overcoming the high resistance that can hinder electron flow in the cathode. According to numerous studies, improving the energy density and cycle life of SSLMBs is not unrelated to the structural design of the electrodes or the intercalation hybridization of the materials. Therefore, it is necessary to develop multi-dimensional and multi-scale Al-based material dopants to facilitate ion and electron transport to a greater extent and stabilize the electrode structure, achieving potent SSLMB performance characteristics. The doping and addition methods of Al-based material dopants also need to be further explored and optimized to better understand their mechanism of action in SSLMBs, leading to battery systems with enhanced safety and improved electrochemical performance. In addition, the interaction of Al-based material dopants with other components must be considered. Unstable doping may impact the final battery’s cycle life and safety, necessitating further research to understand its deep mechanisms. (3) The problem of lithium dendrite growth on the anode side of SSLMBs severely limits the development process, and there is an urgent need to construct a stable electrolyte/lithium metal anode interface. Li-Al alloys have been demonstrated to be a stable and reversible anode electrode and can effectively inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites, so in-situ growth of Al alloys at the electrolyte/lithium anode interface is necessary. In addition, on the basis of clarifying the growth mechanism of lithium dendrites, the interaction between Al alloys and lithium dendrites should be investigated, and scientific strategies should be used to give full play to the role of Al-based material dopants and inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. (4) In addition to the two important constituent components, SSE and electrode materials, Al-based material dopants have some other key roles in SSLMBs. For instance, there is space for further research on current collectors. Al-based material dopants generally exhibit high Li+ conductivity in SSLMBs, which greatly enhance electrochemical performance and safety. However, some studies also indicate that high-loading electrodes based on low-conductivity Al foil still can affect the battery’s areal capacity and energy density, posing serious challenges for high-performance SSLMB. Researchers are exploring surface treatments and interfacial engineering techniques to improve the contact and integration between the Al current collector and the SSE. As SSLMB technology evolves, more researches are needed to design and optimize the structure of Al current collectors as well as the electrochemical reconfiguration of the Al foil electrodes during cycling in the future to further enhance the cell performance. (5) In-depth exploration of the mechanism through a single characterization technique is limited. In addition to conventional electrochemical testing methods, in-situ characterization techniques with high resolution capabilities should be used to observe the changes in physical and electrochemical behaviors of the SSLMB during charging and discharging in real time, and combined with theoretical calculations to more accurately validate the mechanism of action of Al-based material dopants in SSE, electrodes, interfacial engineering, and thermodynamic behaviors. Considering the cost of Al and its role in critical battery components, maximizing battery performance, reducing costs, improving safety and enhancing other performance aspects are essential for industrial production and commercial applications. However, SSLMB systems based on Al-based material dopants are currently limited to the laboratory stage due to a number of challenges, which require an accelerated pace of improvement. With ongoing researching advancements, Al is poised to drive the development of high-performance SSLMBs towards a more sustainable and energy-efficient battery in the future. coredata.dc:description: As the world transitions to green energy, there is a growing focus among many researchers on the requirement for high-efficient and safe batteries. Solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs) have emerged as a promising alternative to traditional liquid lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), offering higher energy density, enhanced safety, and longer lifespan. The rise of SSLMBs has brought about a transformation in energy storage, with aluminum (Al)-based material dopants playing a crucial role in advancing the next generation of batteries. The review highlights the significance of Al-based material dopants in SSLMBs applications, particularly its contributions to solid-state electrolytes (SSEs), cathodes, anodes, and other components of SSLMBs. Some studies have also shown that Al-based material dopants effectively enhance SSE ion conductivity, stabilize electrode and SSE interfaces, and suppress lithium dendrite growth, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance of SSLMBs. Despite the above mentioned progresses, there are still problems and challenges need to be addressed. The review offers a comprehensive insight into the important role of Al in SSLMBs and addresses some of the issues related to its applications, endowing valuable support for the practical implementation of SSLMBs.
